Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 09:52AM maltomlin wrote: I really feel for your loss. I'm so sorry. Malx
Posts.Title: I Mourn but yet I'm Grateful Frankie_ Frankie_

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 11:57AM maltomlin wrote: Hi The waiting really is the hardest.............BC doesn't care if you've lived a healthy life etc.........it comes whatever. Just take heart that there are many of us who have gone thro' the dx, treatment etc and are now enjoying life again. Most don't come back............they are getting on with their lives.........and that's good. When you're first dx, it's the pits............I had my funeral planned.............but it does get better.........honestly. I'm now over 5 years from a grade 3 & 3/24 positive nodes dx and planning my holidays for the year.  Where you are now is the worst possible place.........but it will get better. Take care
Posts.Title: Diagnosed a week ago... Swissmiss edwards750

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 11:01AM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm so sorry for your dx. You look so young, although it's terrible whatever age you are. Although I didn't have the same results as you, and I was 56 when dx, the feeling are still the same. It's nearly 5 years since my dx and I went thro' the whole treatment including chemo. I'm feeling great now and back to enjoying life again but those early days were really dreadful, so I know how you are feeling. I know it's been said many times, but you will feel better once you know your treatment plan, and what you have to do to beat this. Good luck
Posts.Title: Diagnosed in December with IDC EverydaySparkle msphil

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2013 12:04PM maltomlin wrote: Don't google too much. You can find a lot of negative stuff on there, but there are a lot of folks, like me, who are over it and getting on with life. It doesn't mean that we've forgotten what it was like, just that we'd rather not remember. But we never forget. xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed in December with IDC EverydaySparkle msphil

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 02:38PM maltomlin wrote: When I had my core biopsy etc, the doctor told me that he thought it would be cancer, but to wait for the path results. They confirmed it. I found it helpful (sort of) that I already knew the outcome (I did already. I knew in my heart what it was), but I still had to wait for a week for the official outcome. It gave me time 'to get my head round it', which I did, and I was more level-headed when I rec'd the official dx. It's a hard time....no doubt about it......I had my funeral planned. But here I am 5 years out. The funeral plan is still there on my PC & my hospital bag is still gathering  dust on top of the wardrobe. Just take a day at a time and don't look too far ahead.  Take care xx
Posts.Title: Extremely worried! No answers VAL1966 VAL1966

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 10:47AM maltomlin wrote: That's a great post Marin. There are too few people who come back to say 'how it is'. Those on this forum are mainly those who are going through treatment or having problems and that's all that the newly dx see. I'm coming up to 5 years out and there are thousands of ladies who have gotten over the treatment and are out enjoying themselves. Good luck (you won't need it). Mal
Posts.Title: 8 years ago today... FitChik shorfi

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2010 10:35PM maltomlin wrote: I had a CT scan and X ray at dx which showed a lesion on the liver. Consequently I had a follow-up CT nearing the end of chemo (which showed a cyst). Nothing now unless I present with symptoms and I am happy with that. I don't want to be worried about annual scans etc. Mal
Posts.Title: Stage II ladies, how often do you get PET/CT scans? Fearless_One jan508

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 10:55PM maltomlin wrote: Hi there I'm sorry you've got to go thro this but it is worth it. I'm nearly 5 years post dx and chemo, and it's just a distant dream. Another life. My chemo was epi which is the same as adriamycin. It was hard but doable. I had just about every side effect possible but I'm still here and am doing well. It's a hard drug but if you keep your head down, & mark the treatments off on the calendar, you'll soon be out the other side. Take it easy, don't google, go with the flow & message me if you need to, & you'll soon be over it. Chemo is no easy road, but it is worth it. xx
Posts.Title: hello! diagnosed in 2/2013 denvergal99 maltomlin

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2013 01:33AM maltomlin wrote: Hi again Like you, I did manage to work through treatment, although looking back it wasn't a great idea. I would have 3 or 4 days off each cycle, but my employer was great. Some days I just hit a brick wall at lunchtime and had to go home to bed. I was on a trial so had 8 cycles every 2 weeks instead of 3, which meant that I really didn't have a good week.  The best advice I can give you is to listen to your body. Have something to look forward to. When you're tired....rest etc. As for the loss of taste, I found tomato based food tasted best, but you could be different. I had the Neulasta shots too, but the Cancer hospital where I was treated recommended Manuka honey. A spoonful a day, and I absolutely swear by that. I still take it now. It's good for your immune system and blood count. Chemo is so scary but it's soon over & is so worth it. Take care
Posts.Title: hello! diagnosed in 2/2013 denvergal99 maltomlin

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2012 04:36PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm from the UK , was dx nearly 5 years ago and have to tell you that it's very different here. We're not offered any medication. It didn't bother me as I've always been totally against anti-depressants etc unless they were absolutely vital. I've gone through the dx, surgery, chemo and rads without anything at all (and I think that's normal here).  It was hard in the early days but I think that you find your own way of dealing with it, which you have to do in the long term. I had no medicinal 'props' and I'm glad of that now. It's taken a while to 'get my head round things', but as I  said, sooner or later you have to do that anyway. I know everyone is different, but here we just aren't offered anything. Perhaps if I'd asked............but I didn't and I'm glad.
Posts.Title: To tranquilise or not to tranquilise jebdra Momine

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2013 02:33PM maltomlin wrote: My mammo showed a lump which didn't bear any resemblance to the lump they removed at surgery. It's not a dx until after surgery. I had my funeral planned and was making memory boxes..........but here I am nearly 5 years later and absolutely fine. Wait for the results of the surgery, get your treatment plan, batten down the hatches for a while, and you'll soon be over it, enjoying life again. It's a scary time, but don't google, and don't look too far ahead. Just cross each bridge as you come to it. Take care
Posts.Title: 10cmx9cm big lump - super scared :( Skynet KeepMoving

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 12:14PM maltomlin wrote: Hi there And I'm sorry to intrude! I don't have mets but am high risk as I had a very agressive cancer plus lots of nodes involved. I don't frequent these boards too often but read sometimes. For myself, I think I will be joining your club before too long and I find it 'uplifting' to read the posts. My main question is......................... do I really want to know if I've got mets? Or should I just go along in blissful ignorance? What are the benefits either way?  Mal PS I admire all of you who are fighting this disease but I'm not sure that's for me.
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 10:52AM maltomlin wrote: netty46 I was told the same thing 'it's comes back to the breast' and so my BS recommended WLE. To be honest, I've never regretted it (a mangled boob but can live with that). I just hope that 'if' it comes back it will be in the breast. The normal reaction is to have a mx, and just 'get rid of them' but my BS talked me out of that. I hope I don't live to regret it.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy carries lower overall survival Afraid Momine

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 10:19AM maltomlin wrote: Hi I was dx with a grade 3 tumour over 4 years ago at 57. Chemo was recommended and I was terrified (as I'm sure everyone is). I had 8 cycles and am so glad that I didn't let fear stand in the way. Yes, I felt really ill sometimes and had loads of SE but the hairloss didn't really bother me (I wore a wig to go out and my hair grew back very quickly). Two cyber friends and one real friend refused chemo and they are all gone now. The real friend was simply too scared and expected to have a few years left, but she was gone in 18 months. Whilst there are no guarantees, and no-one knows if my friends would have survived longer post chemo, I just think that a few months of feeling 'rough' is worth the chance. Take care.
Posts.Title: Choosing not to do chemo allformymom maltomlin

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2013 05:03PM maltomlin wrote: Hi You're in the worst possible place right now and it's scary! Just know that I'm nearly 5 years out and doing well.It's really scary at first but just  don't look too far ahead, cross each bridge as you come to it. Don't look ahead and don't google. Life will return to normal but it does take time. Mal xx
Posts.Title: New and Nervous, trying not to freak out. HotPinkMess FilterLady

Posts.Content: May 29, 2013 12:18PM maltomlin wrote: It's a scary time. I'm now over 5 years out from dx. I'm OK and am looking forward to holidays etc. xx
Posts.Title: Scared LanaM Sparkytheimp

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2011 02:07PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I was dx three and a half years ago - grade 3 and 3 positive nodes. Like you I scared myself silly looking at the stats until I realised that they really don't show how you, as an individual, will respond to treatment or what your outcome will be. I'm still here, feeling great, have changed the priorities in my life and plan on going nowhere! One thing I was told was that grade 3 cancers (faster growing) respond to chemo better as the cells are dividing more rapidly. It maybe that you won't need chemo, just hormone treatment (I've been on femara for 3 years without any problems). It's early days for you yet (a scary place) and you will feel much better and more positive once you have a treatment plan in place. We've all been where you are (I planned my funeral as I convinced myself I wouldn't see the next year) but it honestly does get better. I look back now and it's as though it happened to someone else. Like a bad dream I woke from.  You'll get there too. Take care Mal
Posts.Title: Grade 3 - what should I know? QuinnCat QuinnCat

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 07:30AM - edited Dec 27, 2010 07:31AM by maltomlin Just wanted to wish you girls well. It's 2 years since I finished chemo - 4 x dose dense epi followed by 4 x xeloda (I was on a trial).I didn't have a port and my veins were OK for the 4 IV chemos. I was scared stiff at the prospect of chemo and remember sitting in the chair on the first morning thinking 'get me out of here!'. But the chemo was nowhere near as bad as I was expecting. It's not pleasant, and not something you would choose but if you batten down the hatches you are soon out the other side, forgetting what it was like (a bit like labour). You will feel rough sometimes, you will look in the mirror and wonder who it is staring back at you, but you will get through it. Your hair will grow back as normal (although it can take a while) and you will have a new look at life. You will make the most of everything and appreciate everything. Life will be good. Good luck Mal
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 02:12PM maltomlin wrote: I think a lot depends on the position of the lump and also the size. I had a lumpectomy, and have not regretted that decision, but my breast is 'mangled'. The lump was 3cm and was on the inner side of my breast (towards the centre of the breastbone). I have to be careful when I'm buying a dress as my cleavage is non-existant on that side. But I'm happy with my decision as in normal clothes, you really can't tell. I had rads which didn't give me any trouble at all. I'm still happy with with my lumpectomy although I may not have been if I was younger (I'm nearly 60). Mal
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Carola32 maltomlin

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2013 04:45PM maltomlin wrote: OK, mine was over 3cms, grade 3 and 3 positive lymph nodes. Don't worry. I'm still here, absolutely great & plan to be for a long time. I know how scary it is though. When I heard that it was grade 3 with 3 lymph nodes involved and lymphatic invasion, I was scared stiff. But as time goes by (5 years now) you ease up on the worrying. You'll get there. xx
Posts.Title: Still feeling a little woozy Alikat123 Alikat123

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 02:37PM maltomlin wrote: Sorry to intrude but I just came across this thread and what a wonderful group. The support is so important. I just wanted to say congratulations to those who have finished and to those of you who haven't - it will soon come. It's nearly 2 years since I finished 8 rounds of chemo and I have just one bit of advice- Give yourself time to recover! It can take a while but we're all different. I too was on a high when I finished chemo but it took a while for the energey levels to recover, and I was still depressed looking in the mirror. My hair looked like a 60's perm for over 12months! Nearly 2 years on and I'm virtually back to normal. My hair is past shoulder length with just the remnants of curl at the ends. Don't expect to be back-to-normal immediately. You will be disappointed, but celebrate the end of treatment. Mal
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 01:44PM maltomlin wrote: Hi You are in the worst possible place right now, but it will get better. Take it from one who knows. It's a really scary place to be when you are first dx, especially when you're still undergoing tests etc. That's natural. I had my funeral all planned out......that was 5 years ago. Get your treatment plan and you'll feel better. You know what you have to do then to get over it and get on with your life. I was exactly where you are now, 5 years ago, but with a grade 3 and 3 lymph nodes involved and I was scared to death. It's natural.  It will get better..........honestly. Take care Mal
Posts.Title: Hello myboby123 maltomlin

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2013 10:50AM maltomlin wrote: Every one is different. I'm sure if I'd had young kids at home etc I would have felt differently, but for me, the normality of going to work was good for me. I worked through chemo, although looking back, I wasn't really fit & I couldn't give it 100%, but it did help, and my employer was brilliant. If I felt unwell, I went home at lunchtime. That helped a lot. Do what is right for you.
Posts.Title: work the day after phone call of biopsy results lovewins lovewins

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 04:45PM maltomlin wrote: Glad it's not just me! Two years out and no problems but I still find it hard to sleep on my affected side. My shoulders and arm ache if I sleep on  that side. Mal x
Posts.Title: Pain/discomfort on radiated side (ribs?) when waking up bejuce AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2013 07:37PM maltomlin wrote: Hi Fay Like you I'm in Manchester. I was dx 5 years ago, at 56, although not triple negative, I'm OK. I was treated at the Christie and you can't get better treatment. I would recommend them. My friend was dx 4 years ago with triple negative, and although chemo had little effect on the cancer, she is fine. I had the same operation as you and it was OK (just remember to do the exercises). It's a really scary time for you right now but we have the best cancer centre in the country locally, and once you have all the facts & your treatment plan, you'll feel as though you're 'fighting back'. Just message me if you need to.  xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with triple negative invasive ducal cancer faynmoc terrilynn

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 05:58PM maltomlin wrote: Hi. I'm almost 5 years out from dx but your comments struck a cord. After my surgery (WLE + node removal) it was a long, long time before the pain/discomfort went away. It still hasn't completely. Cording was a problem for quite a few months and then it was just general pain/discomfort. I took my grandchildren ten tin bowling last year, 4 years post op and it was so painful. I took them again last month and 'no problem'. Although we're ok now, we're always aware of problems in that area. Take care.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Incision Concern - Tamoxifen Advice MichelleLee maltomlin

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 04:21PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm 5 years post dx, lost weight during chemo but in the 5 years on Femara  have put on a considerable amount of weight. Am I worried? no. I'm still here & that's the main thing. It's all about priorities. In the grand scheme of things, weight doesn't matter as long as you're getting exercise. There will be plenty of time to look at your weight after the treatment is over. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo & weight gain! Lou4of7 Lou4of7

Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 03:27PM maltomlin wrote: I know how scary this is. It'a terrifying. And what to do. It's over 4 years since I was in your shoes but remember it well. Chemo? Don't be silly, I'll be fine. It seemed that it wasn't an option for me 'cos I had nodes involved. I was terrified of having chemo, but needn't have been. It's a scary time for you, but whatever treatment is recomended, you should do. None of it is as bad as our minds would have us believe, and I'm a firm believer in giving a few months to treatment in exchange for having  our lives back. 4 years  on and I do have my life back but even better than before. My priorities have changed and I now appreciate things that I never did before.  I'm really sorry you're going through this but you will come through it. Just accept the treatment. It will soon be over.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed today Roxie1 lightandwind

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 03:11PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm so sorry you're going thro' this. I'm from the UK so can't help with insurance etc. My dx was very similar to yours, grade 3 and a 3cm tumour. After surgery the lab report showed 3 nodes affected, so I needed chemo. Yours could be very different. It's a scary time though even without MS. Your head is all over the place and every ache and pain takes on a sinister thought. It's natural. I'm now nearly 5 years out and the sinister thoughts have mainly gone (just now and again). Life is good again. I don't know what unique challenges you will confront, suffering from MS, but I wish you all the best and hope you'll be back on the boards in a few years offering your support. Take care
Posts.Title: Diagnosed recently Kimberly1965 dlb823

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 05:41PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm sorry you've had this dx. It's a truly terrible time. I know when I was first dx that I really, really thought I was going to die. I even made a document on my PC about my wishes for when I was gone. That document is still there, on my PC, nearly 5 years post dx. And it will stay there. Just as my hospital bag, complete with wig, will stay on top of the wardrobe gathering dust. It's natural to feel that way, but you should remember that many ladies have got through this and are enjoying life. They don't come here anymore, they're enjoying their life. The treatment isn't easy but is worth it. I'm off now. Cruising in the Caribbean in 2 weeks. Life is good. Good luck. xx
Posts.Title: recently diagnosed misshopeful misshopeful

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 11:48PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I know I'm nearly 5 years out from dx but still feel it's relevant (I am also from the UK, which is slightly different). After my dx I was given the choice of lumpectomy or mastectomy and I asked my surgeon what he would recommend if it was  his wife. He said 'lumpectomy' 'cos if it came back it would (likely) do so in the same breast, which is a lot easier to treat after a lumpectomy. I had the lumpectomy. The lump was a lot bigger than they they had estimated and my breast is 'mangled' but I'm still glad that I went for that option. Once dressed no-one could tell. It was a good choice. It's such a hard decision, made when you're feeling at your most vulnerable. I know some people just 'want it off' and whilst I  can understand that, I just want you to know that a lumpectomy + rads is just as effective. I'm still here nearly five years after dx, and after chemo and rads, and feeling really good. Take care.
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2014 04:42PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I was dx with grade 3 and 3 nodes involved....that was 6 years ago. After my surgery I asked for the chemo treatment to be put back until I'd had my holiday with my family.......no problem.....good idea. I came back feeling refreshed and ready for chemo (if anyone is). It's important to spend time with your family and not get wrapped up in 'cancer land'.......life will be good again...........
Posts.Title: Can I delay treatment after surgery? goofytoo goofytoo

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 04:39PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I hope you don't mind if I butt in ladies. 18 months ago I was exactly where daisylego is now. I was DX stage 2B and as 3 nodes were affected I had a CT scan. It showed nodes in my liver and adrenal gland. I was absolutely scared stiff. My onc 'couldn't rule out secondaries' and (like Shirley's) ordered a PET scan which showed them benign. I had a follow-up scan a few months later just to make sure. So here I am, still stage 2B. Hopefully you will be just the same. Take care Mal
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2014 02:47PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I too had extensive LVI.........that was nearly 6 years ago.........I'm fine. Really, don't worry yourself silly about it.........the treatment will do its job. Concentrate on getting thro' this and enjoying your family. Mal
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2014 06:28PM maltomlin wrote: You're all doing great girls,,,,,,,,chemo is the pits & you just have to put your head down and get it over......it soon is. I know some people have no side effects, and that's great, but the majority of us do.......but it doesn't last long.......soon you'll be out the other side.......getting over it..........and then looking forward to future holidays, or time with the kids..........whatever makes you happy. Hair??It soon comes back....maybe not as you would like, initially, it takes a while. But it will come back. Mal
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo January 6, 2014 desimone birdlover23

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2013 03:00PM maltomlin wrote: Hi It's easy to say 'don't worry' but I agree with everything said. I'm now 5 years out but remember those early days so well. Planning my funeral etc etc. It's all still there, but I've not needed it. I've just returned from a Caribbean cruise and the next is Norway. It's an awful time when you're first dx but it does get better, honestly. You'll enjoy life again and the treatment will be a distant memory. Take care
Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 08:04AM maltomlin wrote: Hi What is the right thing to do? I know I was absolutely stunned when I heard I needed chemo. Was petrified sitting in the chair waiting for the first chemo....and just wanted to run.......... Then I thought about all the little kids who have chemo.....that did it for me. It honestly wasn't as bad as I'd imagined. No, it's not pleasant but it doesn't last long and if you get your life back it's worth it........isn't it? I thought so. I'm 5 years out from dx, 4 years from chemo and everything is back to normal.....no it's better. I'm sorry you've had a previous dx. That must be so hard to get your head round. But if you're looking for reasons to do chemo...........it's me. I've never felt better. Life is good and chemo is a distant dream (or nightmare). Take care
Posts.Title: deciding on treatment chefstill chefstill

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2014 06:48PM maltomlin wrote: Hi. Chemo is scary but it is good and worthwhile. Ok, you may not feel good when having chemo........then again you may be fine.........we're all different. I'm here to say that it's worthwhile.....I'm still here nearly 6 years on.........after all the neulasta shots, tests etc etc..........it's so worth it. Ok you may not feel so good some days, work is hard to cope with..........but you'll soon be out the other side. You'll soon be back to your new normal.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo January 6, 2014 desimone birdlover23

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 02:00PM maltomlin wrote: 18 months from treatment (the 'full monty chemo etc') and I feel good (not great). The chemo days are like labour pains (soon forgotten) and I'm feeling carefree. Yes the worries are in a box in the back of my mind but I'm feeling good (but different). Take care Mal
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2013 04:40PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm now over 5 years out. Was dx grade 3 with 3 positive nodes. When first dx I googled far too much & scared myself silly. Yes, it's scary, and yes, it's not the results that we wanted to hear. But the treatments are good (great even) and here I am nearly 6 years out. I'm over the chemo, and over the rads, and the femara is fine. I'm enjoying life again (6 grandchildren born since I was dx). Life is good. Mal
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2013 02:04PM - edited Jan 14, 2013 02:07PM by maltomlin Hi You're in a really scary place right now........but it will get better. Honestly. I was dx nearly 5 years ago when I was 56, grade 3 and 3 nodes affected. I really, really thought I was going to die and planned my funeral (the file is still there on my computer). But I didn't, and in fact, I feel absolutely great. No, I wouldn't choose to have chemo but it served its purpose. I'm still here. Whatever treatment you need, it's not too bad and you'll soon be over it and feeling better. I have many friends who have also been dx and they're all doing great. My MIL was dx in her 30's and died at 86 of heart failure. Just remember that the ladies who have recovered and are getting on with their lives don't come on this site. They're too busy enjoying themselves (like me, I don't come here very often). Take care xx
Posts.Title: Will I Die? luckystar netty46

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2010 01:57PM maltomlin wrote: Hi 56 at dx and 2 years later NED. I simply cannot believe the number of young people on here. It was simply devastating for me but cannot imagine how it is for young women with young kids and the whole of their lives in front of them. It makes me feel very humble and selfish. Mal x
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 03:44PM maltomlin wrote: Hi My son is a pharmacist and is doing cancer research, He tells me of all the promising research (which is really over my head), proteins etc and I'm sure that the answer is not long off. In the meantime, just keep going!  The prognosis means nothing. It's not your expiry time. They don't know. My old boss was dx stage 4 over 8 years ago and is still going strong. They just don't know. Keep well Mal
Posts.Title: stage 4 and I'm 29 with a new baby lindyw82 justjudie

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 04:33AM maltomlin wrote: Hi jlynnbain10 We've all been where you are right now and it's the pits! But you will get through it - honestly. You've had some really great advice here. The best was to take a day at a time. That applies until you've finished teatment. Just look no further than your next hospital appointment, test or whatever.  I'm now over 2 years since dx with node involvement and I was absolutley terrified, especially when I discovered that I would need chemo. When I went for my first I had a panic attack just thinking 'let me out of here'. I just wanted to run. I didn't and I spent the next couple of days wondering if they had given me the wrong drugs as I had no side effects. They did come later but nothing that I couldn't deal with. You will too. If I can do it so can you. The hair loss didn't bother me half as much as I expected. Now I've got shoulder length hair and am just debating whether to have it cut or not. This really is the scariest time but it will get better. You will realise who and what are important to you and get rid of the rest. I'm 2 years out and life is really good again. Give yourself time. Take care Mal
Posts.Title: just found out i have IDC ! so scared ! jlynnbain1031 dmorgan2

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 12:57PM maltomlin wrote: Hi We've all been where you are right now and it's the worst possible place, but it will get better. Honestly. I was dx May 2008 had surgery, chemo and rads. Last Christmas I had convinced myself that I wouldn't see another! Here I am now feeling great (still a little tired) not long returned from a snorkelling trip on the Red Sea and life is brilliant. The treatment is hard but doable and you just have to keep your head down and mark them off on the calendar. Aches and pains? I had a scare when something showed  up on my liver but thankfully it was nothing. Every ache and pain was mets! I had everything from mets in my thumb to my big toe! Now I've calmed down but still vigilant. Just be careful about googling too much - you can scare yourself silly. If I can do it anyone can. Mal

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 08:27AM maltomlin wrote: I forgot to put the beef in a beef casserole yesterday - again! And I'm nearly two years out from chemo. Mal x

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 05:51PM maltomlin wrote: Hey girls I just wanted to let you know that there is life after chemo. I'm now 18 months post treatment and remember it so well. You feel as though it's never ending, but you will get through it and enjoy life again. Promise. Just go with the flow and you'll soon be through it. Mal
Posts.Title: May 2010 Chemo fotopet leftduetostupidmods

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 09:59PM maltomlin wrote: Hi girls I'm now 5 years post dx. It's a really scary time for you all. Chemo is a scary word and I know you're all scared stiff (I know I was), but it's OK as long as you make plans for it. Yes, you feel rough sometimes, but you can carry on your life as normal (well almost). I did work through chemo, but don't recommend it. You need time for yourself to regroup (as it were). When working I would hit the proverbial 'brick wall' and had to go home and go to bed, but I did feel 'useful'.   Just concentrate on 'you'. Take time to rest, when your body tells you to, and take things easy. You'll soon be out the other side. xx
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2010 08:24AM maltomlin wrote: Hi My mother-in-law was dx at 32, had a radical mastectomy and three weeks in the 'radium institute'. She is 86 now! It had spead to her nodes too. Take heart. Mal
Posts.Title: 80 years old......???? Mamita49 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2013 05:39AM maltomlin wrote: Hi My tumour was estimated to be 1cm after the biopsy and so I opted for a WLE. It was actually 3.5cms. I still managed a WLE but do have a very mangled boob. It really doesn't bother me. As long as I have something in my bra, I'm not bothered. I could have felt differently if I'd been younger, more self conscious in low cut dresses etc. but at my age (56 at dx) they like it or lump it! So yes, it can change. I know the majority are pleased with a WLE and can see very little change.  I have to say that, I'm still so pleased that I didn't have a mastectomy.
Posts.Title: Tumor Size? summergal maltomlin

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 07:03PM maltomlin wrote: Just wanted to say...... yes you feel rough thro' chemo but just get your head down, mark the treatments off on the calendar and you'll soon be 'on the other side'. I'm nearly 5 years from dx and had the surgery, chemo and rads. It's not a pleasant experience but if you knuckle down it will soon be over. The side effects are short-lived and you will soon be feeling more like your normal self. I am fine now and you will be too. Soon be planning your holidays for next year. You're in a scary place right now though. xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed in November, have questions! NurseLeeLee Melrosemelrose

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 03:57AM maltomlin wrote: Love to you and your family. Mal
Posts.Title: How do you say goodbye? Nanalinda konakat

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 05:42PM maltomlin wrote: Hi. I'm with Claire_in_Seattle and Beeb75 on this one. I'm in the UK so it maybe slightly different but I am being treated by one of the two major cancer centres in the UK. I should add that I have absolute faith in both my BS and Onc who are wonderful. I had level i and ii clearance as they felt it important to 'get all the cancer' out. 24 nodes were removed and 3 were affected. My Bs told me the same as Beeb75 has said, that it is the ratio that is important. 3 out of 24 giving a better prognosis than 3 out of 10. Full movement was regained very quickly although the area was numb for over a year. I have no problems whatsoever now. Many of my friends and colleagues had full clearance (some many years ago) and I don't know of anyone with any problems. These matters should be discussed fully with your doctors. Whilst lymphedema is a risk to all us all I don't think that scaremongering is good for anyone, especially those seeking  some re-assurance. Mal
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Dissection Sereena thenewme

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2011 06:06PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm afraid I didn't do the combo you mention but hopefully someone will come  along soon. It's now 3 years since I finished chemo but I remember being scared stiff sitting in the chemo chair for the first time. I just wanted to run away but it wasn't nearly as bad as I was expecting although I had all the common side effects. We're all different and we all react differently to the chemo so there's no way to predict how you will feel. I found the fatigue the worst thing although I did manage to work (on reduced hours). Hopefully chemo will be kind to you. Take care Mal
Posts.Title: Starting chemo... NERVOUS LeannaClem Bonseye

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2013 03:06PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I was in the same boat over 5 years ago. Found the lump (knew immediately), waited for Drs appointment, then biopsy etc. I didn't tell the kids (all grown) until I had the result. Didn't want to say 'I think.......' or the 'doctor thinks.......' I wanted to KNOW for definite. I was 'happy' with that. It also gave me time 'to get my head round it'. There's no rush. Just tell them when you're ready.

Posts.Title: Need emotional help Nickie69 Heidihill

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 10:00PM maltomlin wrote: Don't be frightened. I know it's easier said than done, We're all frightened when we're in your position, It does get better though. I was so frightend at the start I had already planned my funeral. I'm now 2 years out from dx and still remember vividly how frightened I felt. Your treatment plan  will make you feel as though you have a handle on it and will make you feel in control. Plenty more people will be along to offer advice but my advice is - just take a day at a time and don't google too much (it will make you worry yourself silly). Just take a day at a time. Mal x
Posts.Title: Please help Rachel1 mawhinney

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2013 04:31PM maltomlin wrote: Hi Girls I just stumbled on this thread and wanted to give some support. I'm now 5 years out from chemo but remember it wel!!!!!!! It's so scary sitting in the chair waiting for the first....I just wanted to run........The rest isn't fun either, but it is worth it in the long run. You will get through this. I'm 5 years out and doing great. Listen to your body, rest when you need to, and live it up when you can. xx
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2013 04:15PM maltomlin wrote: Please don't worry about the timescale. Even a grade 3 cancer (like mine) doesn't spread that quickly. I was really worried when dx with a grade 3 and 3 positivie nodes, but put the scheduled chemo off for a week to go on a family holiday. A week or two doesn't make any difference. Likewise, it doesn't make any difference putting off the surgery to 'think about it'. When I was first dx my instinct was to have a mastectomy, but when I asked my surgeon what he would do if it was his wife, he said 'a wle and then if (and that's a big if) it comes back, it will come back as another lump, instead of the chest wall'. I followed his advice and here I am 5 years out, enjoying life. xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed last week AryaS dwill

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2013 04:14PM maltomlin wrote: I wish I had known what came after treatment!! I'm 5 years out from chemo etc but it was a couple of years before I felt anything like OK. I put on a brave face, became a chemo/cancer buddy but it took a while. Longer than I expected. When I had a meeting with my onc last time, I told her that I thought that the phsychogical effects of this disease were under estimated & there should be more work done in this area. I believe that. We have the treatment and then we're just expected 'to get on with our lives'. That's great but it doesn't happen that way. Mal
Posts.Title: What I wished I had known.... PeggySull sciencegal

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 08:51PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I'm now 4 years past dx and nearly the same from chemo. Mine was a similar, high pressure job and one which I had loved for nearly 20 years. Once I started chemo I advised them that I would probably be absent for a few months. I felt dreadful thro' chemo but also felt that I would be much better carrying on working, when I could. Sitting/lying at home just wasn't good for me. My employer was great. 'Come in whenever you can'. So I had a few days off after each chemo session, and as time went on and I felt the fatigue more I went home at lunchtime every day. I found that I was fine in the morning but by lunchtime...... I hit a brickwall and simply had to go home. I needed the workplace as a place to seem normal & didn't want to stay at home feeling sorry for myself. It was good for me. But as soon as I had the chance (once I felt OK) I applied for early retirement. Now? I love not working. Priorities change.
Posts.Title: If you didn't have to work during chemo, would you? Truffles Moonflwr912

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 01:34PM maltomlin wrote: Hi I had a friend dx Feb 10  with Her2+ and postive nodes(she wouldn't say how many nor details of her path report other than grade 3). She refused all treatment other than mastectomy. Basically she was scared of having chemo despite my arguments for it. She just wouldn't talk about it. She was dx with skin mets in April this year which quickly progressed. Still she refused treatment. She died in August. It had spread to her lungs and brain. It's so sad, You have to respect their wishes but for my friend I can't help but think 'what if'..... Mal
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried? Best friend went "natural" route ... beloved1234 Chevyboy

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 01:54PM maltomlin wrote: I know how I felt when I was first dx with BC. Grade 3 with 3/24 affected. Initially told that I wouldn't need chemo etc and then it all changed. I'm over 3 years on from dx  and over 2 years  from treatment. 3 years on and it's a distant memory (a bit like childbirth). It's not pleasant but you do get through it. It's so scary at first. I really didn't think I would survive to see another summer and organised my funeral. But although the treatment is hard, it's worth it. You'll get loads of support from this website, although I think it's worth bearing in mind that all those (like me) who are OK, only come on here rarely - they're getting on with life again. The main contributors to this website are those going through treatment. Take care Mal

Posts.Title: So Now What??? Shanagirl maltomlin

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2014 06:14PM maltomlin wrote: I'm with Wren on this............I don't understand why all patients don't have chemo before surgery. It makes sense to find a chemo that works for you. Nobody wants chemo.......I know I was scared silly when I was told I needed it........but it does the job. No, it's not pleasant.....but it's better than the alternative........and you're soon over it and getting on with your life. I'm here now nearly 6 years out.............enjoying life, planning my next holiday etc..........it was very different a few years ago! It's natural to be scared at the dx and the prospect of the treatment............but the treatment does work for the majority of people.
